Macros

 A result of failure for functions that return db_result_t. More...

 A result of failure for functions that return db_wtime_t. More...

 A result of failure for functions that return db_len_t. More...

 Save the current error code to an ErrorInfo. More...

 Restore the current error code from an ErrorInfo. More...
 
#define DB_PUSH_ERROR(__error_info__)   save_db_error(__error_info__)
 Store the current error code. More...
 
#define DB_POP_ERROR(__error_info__)   restore_db_error(__error_info__)
 Restore the current error code. More...
 
#define DB_SET_ERROR(x)   set_db_error(x)
 Set the given error code. More...
 
#define DB_RAISE_ERROR(x)   return DB_SET_ERROR(x)
 Set the given error code and return it to the caller. More...
 
#define DB_THROW_ERROR(x)   do { int __rc__ = (x); if (DB_FAILED(__rc__)) DB_RAISE_ERROR(__rc__); } while (false)
 If x is an error, throw it to the caller. More...
 
#define DB_ONERROR_GOTO(x, lab)   do { int __rc__ = (x); if (DB_FAILED(__rc__)) goto lab; } while (false)
 If x is an error, go to lab. More...
 
#define DB_ONERROR_RET(x, result)   do { int __rc__ = (x); if (DB_FAILED(__rc__)) return result; } while (false)

Detailed Description

Errors, warnings, return codes, and related helper functions.

Many errors can occur during a C API function call. When an error occurs, an error code is set that indicates the kind of error encountered. To retrieve the most recent error code, call get_db_error. You can check the error code with DB_SUCCESS or DB_FAILED to determine whether the call was successful. Some error codes are only warnings, and are considered success. Warnings are represented by positive values, while errors are indicated by negative values.

You can also check whether a C API function call was successful by inspecting the return value. Many API functions return a value of type db_result_t. In this case, the value is either DB_OK if the call was successful, or DB_FAIL if not. Any function that returns a handle type (e.g. db_t) will return NULL in case of failure.

The following list indicates what value will be returned when a function with the given return type encounters an error:

  • db_result_t: DB_FAIL
  • db_wtime_t: DB_WTIME_FAIL
  • db_len_t: DB_LEN_FAIL
  • db_t: NULL
  • db_row_t: NULL
  • db_cursor_t: NULL
  • db_sequence_t: NULL
  • db_hlock_t: NULL
  • db_coltype_t: NULL
  • db_vartype_t: NULL

See also

◆ DB_ENOSPACE

#define DB_ENOSPACE   -5

No space available.

◆ DB_EIO

#define DB_EIO   -6

I/O error.

Error reading or writing from disk or other permanent storage.

◆ DB_EACCESS

#define DB_EACCESS   -7

File cannot be opened due to invalid access mode or insufficient file system privileges.

See also
db_create_file_storage, db_open_file_storage

◆ DB_EEXTEND

#define DB_EEXTEND   -8

File operation is out of file size.

◆ DB_EDEADLOCK

#define DB_EDEADLOCK   -9

Unable to lock - deadlock condition detected.

This error occurs under shared access when an operation cannot be completed because of a deadlock condition.

A deadlock condition occurs when two concurrent transactions hold locks on the same rows such that neither can complete until the other is finished.

To handle this error, abort the transaction and start over.

This error only occurs if a deadlock is detected. Some deadlocks involving more than two transactions cannot be detected and will result in a DB_ELOCKED error when the operation times out.

◆ DB_ELOCKED

#define DB_ELOCKED   -10

Unable to acquire lock.

The operation cannot be completed because a necessary resource is locked.

The locked resource can be either a schema object such as a table or index, or a row in a table.

A table's schema cannot be modified while there is an open cursor for that table. If this error is encountered when attempting to modify table columns or indexes, ensure that all cursors for that table have been closed.

When modifying a row in a table, DB_ELOCKED will occur if the row cannot be locked within the timeout period.

◆ DB_EINVAL

#define DB_EINVAL   -11

Invalid argument.

◆ DB_ERANGE

#define DB_ERANGE   -12

Argument is out of range.

◆ DB_ESTATE

#define DB_ESTATE   -13

Object state is not compatible with the method called or arguments.

◆ DB_ENOTIMPL

#define DB_ENOTIMPL   -14

The requested functionality is not implemented in the current library package.

Library configuration cannot be set by a client when using the client/server package.

This package produce the error DB_ENOTIMPL when db_set_config, db_get_config, lm_set_config, lm_get_config, or lm_use_local is called. Instead, these parameters can be set when the server is run. See the documentation for dbserver in the User's Guide for options.

Lock manager configuration is not available when using the single-user package because no lock manager is used.

◆ DB_ENOMEM

#define DB_ENOMEM   -15

[HY001] No memory available for allocation.

◆ DB_EOSERROR

#define DB_EOSERROR   -16

General operating system error.

See also
db_create_file_storage, db_open_file_storage

◆ DB_SUCCESS

#define DB_SUCCESS (   x)    ((int32_t)(x) >= DB_NOERROR)

Test whether an error code represents a successful result.

Parameters
xError code to be tested.
Returns
true when the operation that set x was successful.
See also
DB_FAILED, Error Handling

◆ DB_FAILED

#define DB_FAILED (   x)    ((int32_t)(x) < DB_NOERROR)

Test whether an error code represents a failed result.

Parameters
xError code to be tested.
Returns
true when the operation that set x was not successful.
See also
DB_SUCCESS, Error Handling

Store the current error code.

Parameters
__error_info__Destination for the error code.

◆ DB_POP_ERROR

#define DB_POP_ERROR (   __error_info__)    restore_db_error(__error_info__)

Restore the current error code.

Parameters
__error_info__Source of the error code.

◆ DB_SET_ERROR

#define DB_SET_ERROR (   x)    set_db_error(x)

Set the given error code.

Parameters
xthe error code.
See also
DB_THROW_ERROR, DB_RAISE_ERROR

◆ DB_RAISE_ERROR

#define DB_RAISE_ERROR (   x)    return DB_SET_ERROR(x)

Set the given error code and return it to the caller.

Parameters
xthe error code.
See also
DB_THROW_ERROR, DB_SET_ERROR

◆ DB_THROW_ERROR

#define DB_THROW_ERROR (   x)    do { int __rc__ = (x); if (DB_FAILED(__rc__)) DB_RAISE_ERROR(__rc__); } while (false)

If x is an error, throw it to the caller.

Otherwise, continue.

Parameters
xthe error code.
See also
DB_RAISE_ERROR, DB_SET_ERROR, DB_ONERROR_GOTO

◆ DB_ONERROR_GOTO

#define DB_ONERROR_GOTO (   x,
  lab 
)    do { int __rc__ = (x); if (DB_FAILED(__rc__)) goto lab; } while (false)

If x is an error, go to lab.

Otherwise, continue.

Parameters
xthe error code.
lablabel to go to in case of error.
See also
DB_RAISE_ERROR, DB_SET_ERROR, DB_THROW_ERROR

◆ DB_ENOTFOUND

#define DB_ENOTFOUND   -101

When attempting to modify a schema object, DB_ENOTFOUND indicates that the schema object could not be found.

Item not found.

This error also occurs when attempting to fetch data from a cursor that is not positioned on any row, and when a seek operation yields no result.

See also
db_fetch, db_seek

◆ DB_EINDVALUE

#define DB_EINDVALUE   -145

This error can occur when inserting, updating, or executing an SQL query with parameters.

Length indicator value exceeds buffer size or is an invalid negative number.

To avoid this error, do not specify a length that exceeds the buffer size, and do not use a negative value other than:

  • DB_NTS
  • DB_FIELD_NULL

Note that the length indicator is measured in characters, whereas the buffer size is measured in bytes.

See also
db_insert, db_update, db_execute

◆ DB_ENULLFIELD

#define DB_ENULLFIELD   -146

This error will also occur a NOT NULL field is added to a non-empty table, or when a column containing null values is set to NOT NULL.

Insert or update would violate a NOT NULL constraint, or primary key must be NOT NULL.

See also
db_insert, db_update, db_execute, db_add_field, db_update_field

◆ DB_ETXSTATE

#define DB_ETXSTATE   -191

Schema modifications such as creating a table can only be performed when no transaction is active.

The operation cannot be performed in the current transaction state.

Data modifications such as inserting a row must be performed while a transaction is active. Otherwise a DB_ETXSTATE error will occur.

Typedef Documentation

◆ dbstatus_t

typedef int dbstatus_t

Error code type: indicates success, warning, or error condition.

See also
Error Handling

◆ db_result_t

typedef struct rc_s* db_result_t

API call result.

See also
DB_OK, DB_FAIL, Error Handling

Function Documentation

◆ set_db_error()

dbstatus_t set_db_error ( dbstatus_t  rc_t)

Set error code.

Note
Do not call this function directly. Use DB_SET_ERROR instead.
Parameters
rc_terror code
See also
DB_THROW_ERROR, DB_RAISE_ERROR, DB_SET_ERROR

◆ get_db_error()

dbstatus_t get_db_error ( void  )

Get the most recent error code.

Note
This value is not cleared by any API calls except clear_db_error. To check for an error in any of a series of calls, first call clear_db_error, then call each API function, and finally use get_db_error to check the result.
Returns
the last error code that was set.
See also
clear_db_error

◆ clear_db_error()

dbstatus_t clear_db_error ( void  )

Clear the current error code.

See also
get_db_error

◆ save_db_error()

void save_db_error ( ErrorInfo *  )

Save the current error code to an ErrorInfo.

◆ restore_db_error()

void restore_db_error ( const ErrorInfo *  )

Restore the current error code from an ErrorInfo.
